I know this does not fall under the legal definition of gay rights, but it's very important in a way.
 
 I feel like gays/lesbians should not be harrassed by others claiming their right to excercise first ammendment stuff.
 
 Everyone is entitled to first ammendment rights, but when people start using that to berate and harass and use scare tatics, I think it crosses the line.

 No.
 
 Do you think the government has the right to defend people from subjective harm?
 
 Under that principle, I can write a book and someone can say, "This book makes me angry and hurts my feelings," and the book would be banned. People will abuse the "subjective harm" principle to pass off all opinions they don't agree with as harmful.
 
 So what if Terral03 speaks rudely? All it does is make him look bad. The honorable person reads his post and thinks "He's a pot-smoking idjot. Let him babble," not "OMG that's so rude let's ban him!"
jitobear

Actually speach that calls for violence against a person is something you can be held to legally - ie,you rally a person(s) to burn a building or kill a man, but you don't do it yourself, you can still be held accountable.
 
 And harassment is illegal.

There is no right to harrass but stating an opinion, even if rudely, does not not constitute harrasment. Simply ignore what you don't wish to see or hear and you will be fine.

And harassment is illegal.
 
 
 If that's true, then Freedom of Speech is doomed. Harassment is subjective. Now I can claim that a book I don't like is harassing me, and it will be banned.
Phunting

A book is harassing you? emoticon_wow I'd get a court order taken out on it.
 
 But yes, of course it is subjective, however just because it is illegal to harass someone (or incitement of racial/religious hatred, which is also illegal) I would hardly say that consitutes the doom of freedom of speech.
 
 As a supreme court justice once said, "Freedom of speech does not include the right to shout 'Fire!' in a crowded theater."

it's free speech until they threaten/harrass you personally. That means they have to address you specifically, making a blanket statement against all gays isn't specific enough to be unprotected.

So basically the only speech that is illegal is running up to someone and saying "I'm gonna kill you!" with full intent, or, as stated earlier, shouting Fire in a crowded theater. I stand corrected.
 
 But if it becomes illegal to say anything that anyone finds offensive, then that crosses the line. Someone could say The Cat in the Hat is offensive and get the book banned. Granted, people should be allowed to say things that offend people. People don't have to listen to them.

Regarding when speach can be limited. I think it comes down to when what is being said causes quantifiable harm. A guy on the street saying thay hate fags, or even "fags like you", would not qualify. Said guy hurting you or your property or inciting others to do so would qualify. 
 
 For harrassment to be a legal issue it has to be demonstrated and consistent (Stalking, several harrassing phone calls) by the same person or organization.
